children.title: time
children.comment: A creation of God which marks the duration of life and which is measured by changes in the created order. The flow of time is directed by God who appoints particular ``times'' within his unfolding purposes. Because human life is brief, time should be used properly, making the most of every opportunity.

cschildren.title: Time as a creation of God

children.title: Time is marked by change in the created order

primaryrefs.comment: The main divisions of time were based upon the phases of the sun and moon.

secondaryrefs.comment: A day was marked by the regular cycle of evening and morning
Months were determined by the regular phases of the moon
The year consisted of twelve lunar months
An hour was one twelfth of the period of daylight.

children.title: A right time for every activity
Times of human life in God's hands

cschildren.title: Appointed times within God's unfolding purpose

children.title: The time of fulfilment of promise

secondaryrefs.comment: the time of John the Baptist's birth
the time of Israel's possession of the land

children.title: The time of Jesus Christ's coming
The time of Jesus Christ's death
The time of Jesus Christ's return
The appointed time of the end

cschildren.title: The time between Jesus Christ's first and second coming

primaryrefs.comment: The time of salvation lies between the two comings of Jesus Christ.

children.title: Recognising the brevity of human life
abolition
children.comment: The final ending and elimination of practices or states of affairs. Scripture looks forward to God's final abolition of the present order, through the inauguration of the new Jerusalem.

cschildren.title: Things to be abolished in the kingdom of God

seealsos.comment: God speaks here of his abolition of sinful, human hard-heartedness

cschildren.title: The abolition of idolatry in Israel

children.title: Israel was commanded to abolish Canaanite worship
The abolition of mediums and spiritists

primaryrefs.comment: Antiochus Epiphanes abolished the daily sacrifice in the temple in 168 B.C., thereby attacking the symbolic centre of Israel's life.

children.title: Jesus Christ was accused of seeking to abolish the temple

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ's action may have been understood as a symbolic abolition of a defiled sacrificial system

children.title: The final abolition of the temple in the new Jerusalem
The law has not been abolished
The law has been abolished as an instrument of condemnation
The law does not abolish God's promises

primaryrefs.comment: God did not abolish his promise of righteousness to Abraham when he gave the law, because the promise was not conditional upon keeping the law but is received by faith.

children.title: The offence of the cross is abolished by accepting circumcision

primaryrefs.comment: Jews found offensive the Christians' claim that salvation did not come through keeping the law, but instead through faith in a crucified Messiah, whom the law had cursed. Paul regarded ``the offence of the cross'' as central to the gospel, and refused to make salvation conditional upon circumcision and obedience to the law.

children.title: beginning
children.comment: A starting point, origin or source. The beginning often refers to the time of or before the creation of the world. God is described as the Beginning and the End, denoting the eternity of his existence. Jesus Christ's coming marks a new beginning both for God's people and, finally, for all creation.

seealsos.comment: the source of Israel's sin
Jesus Christ as the source of the church's life

children.title: Jesus Christ's existence predates the creation
The beginning of signs of the end
God as the Beginning and the End

cschildren.title: Satan as sinful from the beginning

children.title: chance
children.comment: The occurrence of events at random, as undesigned happenings. While people may perceive events as random, in Scripture all events are subject to God's sovereignty.

children.title: Human life seems to be governed by chance, not merit
Providence at work through apparent chance

cschildren.title: Chance events overruled by God's sovereignty

children.title: The casting of lots and the element of chance
Urim and Thummim, seeming to be dependent on chance

primaryrefs.comment: The Urim and Thummim were used by the high priest to declare God's will. It was a form of casting lots showing either an affirmative or negative response to an enquiry.

children.title: completion
children.comment: The bringing to fulfilment of a work, such as the work of creation or redemption.

cschildren.title: Creation was completed by the seventh day

seealsos.comment: Genesis chapter 1 records the creation completed on each successive day as being ``good''

cschildren.title: All things are completed in God's time
The work of redemption is a completed work

children.title: Jesus Christ brought his earthly work to completion
Jesus Christ will present his church complete to his Father
Jesus Christ makes his people complete in himself

cschildren.title: Believers are to complete their God- given work

children.title: This world will come to an end
There will be a final separation of the righteous and wicked
dawn
children.comment: The time marked by the rising of the sun. It signals the end of night and relief from its attendant concerns, and the approach of daylight with the opportunity for renewed daily activity. The light of dawn following darkness is a symbol of hope and vindication, fulfilled especially in the coming of the Messiah through whom God's new age dawns.

cschildren.title: Dawn as the end of the night

children.title: It ends the darkness of the night
It signals the end of nightly activity
Waiting for the dawn to bring relief

cschildren.title: Dawn as the beginning of a new day

children.title: It provides the earliest opportunity of the day

primaryrefs.comment: First light provides the earliest opportunity for action and implies urgency.

seealsos.comment: Dawn was a common time for military campaigns to begin
Women visit Jesus Christ's tomb at dawn
Jesus Christ prays at dawn

cschildren.title: Dawn as a symbol of blessings to come

children.title: The Messiah brings a new dawn
A symbol of hope and vindication
A symbol of God's coming in glory

cschildren.title: Dawn as a symbol of God's revelation
Dawn as a time of reckoning

children.title: Darkness at dawn as a picture of judgment
The light of dawn exposes the wicked
day
children.comment: A period of 24 hours or, as distinct from night, the period of daylight. The term may also be used more generally to refer to a point in time. Daylight is used figuratively to describe the illumination afforded to believers, who are urged to use the opportunities it presents and to avoid the evil usually associated with darkness.

children.title: Day as a period of 24 hours
Day as the period of daylight

cschildren.title: Daylight allows things to be seen

children.title: Daylight activities are seen by all

secondaryrefs.comment: Gideon
Nicodemus

primaryrefs.comment: The Sabbath was reckoned from sunset on Friday to sunset on Saturday.

children.title: The Day of Preparation for the Sabbath (Friday)
The first day of the week (Sunday)

secondaryrefs.comment: Passover and Unleavened Bread
the Day of Atonement
the day of firstfruits

cschildren.title: Day as a point in time

children.title: God sends the day of disaster
God helps on the day of distress

cschildren.title: References to specific periods of days at the end of history

children.title: delay
children.comment: A postponement or pause, which can result from a deliberate decision or a failure to achieve the intended objective in the time available. Scripture stresses that apparent delays on the part of God are due to his love and wisdom, especially to give sinners time for repentance.

children.title: delay, divine
children.comment: Delays by God do not result from any failure on his part, but reflect unrealistic human expectations concerning his actions. God delays his vengeance in order to give time for human repentance.

children.title: God delays to allow for repentance
Where there is no repentance, God does not delay
God delays judgment for the sake of his name
Jesus Christ delayed visiting Lazarus for God's glory
The giving of the Holy Spirit was delayed until Pentecost
God acts when he wants and nothing can delay him

primaryrefs.comment: Referring to the second coming of Jesus Christ.

seealsos.comment: Referring to the LORD's delay in sending the Babylonians to conquer Judah and take her inhabitants into exile

children.title: delay, human
children.comment: Human delay is often the result of fear, indecision or disobedience to God. Scripture indicates that delay is to be avoided.

children.title: Examples of delay as a result of fear
Examples of delay as a result of disobedience

seealsos.comment: Jonah obeyed the second time.

children.title: Nothing should delay believers from following Jesus Christ
People should not delay in the matter of salvation
Believers are not to delay in fulfilling their vows to God and obligations to others
Examples of human responses to delay
Saul's wrong response cost him the kingship
Paul responded by giving instructions to Timothy

seealsos.comment: Gabriel explains the reason for the delay.

children.title: David reponded by calling on the LORD
delay, divine
children.comment: Delays by God do not result from any failure on his part, but reflect unrealistic human expectations concerning his actions. God delays his vengeance in order to give time for human repentance.

children.title: God delays to allow for repentance
Where there is no repentance, God does not delay
God delays judgment for the sake of his name
Jesus Christ delayed visiting Lazarus for God's glory
The giving of the Holy Spirit was delayed until Pentecost
God acts when he wants and nothing can delay him

primaryrefs.comment: Referring to the second coming of Jesus Christ.

seealsos.comment: Referring to the LORD's delay in sending the Babylonians to conquer Judah and take her inhabitants into exile

children.title: delay, human
children.comment: Human delay is often the result of fear, indecision or disobedience to God. Scripture indicates that delay is to be avoided.

children.title: Examples of delay as a result of fear
Examples of delay as a result of disobedience

seealsos.comment: Jonah obeyed the second time.

children.title: Nothing should delay believers from following Jesus Christ
People should not delay in the matter of salvation
Believers are not to delay in fulfilling their vows to God and obligations to others
Examples of human responses to delay
Saul's wrong response cost him the kingship
Paul responded by giving instructions to Timothy

seealsos.comment: Gabriel explains the reason for the delay.

children.title: David reponded by calling on the LORD
end
children.comment: A limit in time or space, or the outcome of a sequence of actions or events. God knows the end from the beginning. He is without limit: he exercises control over the furthest reaches of the world, and will bring to an end earthly powers, human life and the present age. Those who persevere to the end will be saved.

cschildren.title: God is the Beginning and the End
God brings earthly powers to an end

seealsos.comment: Moab
Elam
Israel
Tyre
Egypt
Babylon

children.title: evening
children.comment: The time between the fading of daylight and nightfall. The onset of darkness marks the end of the working day and is a time for rest and refreshment. It is an assigned time for sacrifice and an opportunity for reflection and prayer. The evening also brings dangers.

cschildren.title: Evening marks the end of the day

children.title: Evening and God's work of creation
Days reckoned from evening to evening

secondaryrefs.comment: The Sabbath began at sunset on Friday.

children.title: Executed criminals to be buried by evening

cschildren.title: Evening as a time for refreshment

children.title: A time to rest from labour
A time to rest from travel
A time for reflection and prayer
Lighting the lamps in the sanctuary

primaryrefs.comment: People came to Jesus Christ after sunset, when the Sabbath was over.

seealsos.comment: Water collected in the evening, the coolest time of the day
Red sky in the evening as a sign of fair weather

primaryrefs.comment: Israel's rulers are likened to wolves who prowl in the evening looking for food.

children.title: fate
children.comment: A hidden power which some believe to control and determine everything that happens in such a way that it is impossible to prevent or change things. Scripture stresses both the sovereignty of God and human responsibility and has no place for this pagan notion. The term is also used in a looser sense, to mean ``end'' or ``destiny''.

children.title: fate, and fatalism
children.comment: The belief that all things are predetermined, especially by the stars, removing human freedom and responsibility. Scripture affirms human freedom and responsibility and declares that the sun, moon and stars are all part of God's creation and are subject to him.

children.title: The heavenly bodies subject to God's authority
The heavenly bodies are created by God
The heavenly bodies are subject to the rule and providence of God
The biblical rejection of fatalism in human choice
Human beings are free to choose between right and wrong
Human beings are free to call upon the name of the Lord
Human beings are free to seek the Lord
Human beings are free to come to the Lord
fate, and final destiny
children.comment: The final destiny or predetermined end of individuals, groups or nations.

children.title: The fate of the godly in terms of God's rewards
The fate of the godly in terms of present suffering
The fate of human regulations, institutions and earthly realms
fate, and fatalism
children.comment: The belief that all things are predetermined, especially by the stars, removing human freedom and responsibility. Scripture affirms human freedom and responsibility and declares that the sun, moon and stars are all part of God's creation and are subject to him.

children.title: The heavenly bodies subject to God's authority
The heavenly bodies are created by God
The heavenly bodies are subject to the rule and providence of God
The biblical rejection of fatalism in human choice
Human beings are free to choose between right and wrong
Human beings are free to call upon the name of the Lord
Human beings are free to seek the Lord
Human beings are free to come to the Lord
fate, and final destiny
children.comment: The final destiny or predetermined end of individuals, groups or nations.

children.title: The fate of the godly in terms of God's rewards
The fate of the godly in terms of present suffering
The fate of human regulations, institutions and earthly realms
fulness
children.comment: The totality of something, as it is brought to completion by being filled. Jesus Christ is seen as expressing the full nature and purposes of God, so that believers may rest assured that, through Christ, they know God as he really is. Believers are also being brought to fulness through the gospel, although the final fulness of joy and understanding will take place only in the future kingdom of God.

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ, the fulness of God

children.title: Jesus Christ, the fulness of God's nature
Jesus Christ, the fulness of God's attributes

cschildren.title: Christians and the church enjoy fulness through Jesus Christ
Believers receive fulness of joy from God
The fulness of knowledge and understanding

children.title: Fulness of understanding comes through Jesus Christ
Fulness of understanding is only fully realised when believers see God face to face

cschildren.title: Believers should be constantly filled with the Holy Spirit
Believers receive the fulness of God's love through Jesus Christ
God works out his purposes in the fulness of time

seealsos.comment: Whatever the precise meaning of the phrase ``the times of the Gentiles'', it clearly indicates the sovereignty of God over times and events

cschildren.title: Fulness indicating the completion of God's saving activity amongst both Jews and Gentiles

children.title: history
children.comment: In Scripture, more than a record of and reflection on past events, but a process under God's control which has as its goal the eventual fulfilment of his purposes and through which he makes himself known. The goal of history is realised in Jesus Christ, through whom the age of salvation is inaugurated. Both the OT and NT point to the importance of faith rooted in historical events.

children.title: God's saving purposes worked out through history

cschildren.title: God is known through his people's history

children.title: God is known to his people
God is revealed to the nations

cschildren.title: The Israelites were called to remember their history

children.title: The past was recalled in festivals
The past was recounted to successive generations

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ as the centre of the history of salvation

children.title: He is its beginning and end
God's saving purposes in history fulfilled in Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ inaugurates God's new age

cschildren.title: The Christian faith is based on the historical facts of salvation

children.title: Jesus Christ's resurrection as historical fact
hour
children.comment: One twelfth of the period of daylight between sunrise and sunset. Measurement of time in biblical days was often approximate, referring most frequently to the broad divisions of time marked by the third, sixth and ninth hours. The term also denotes a significant or appointed moment or period of time, especially the hour of Jesus Christ's suffering and his return.

cschildren.title: Hour as a period of time

seealsos.comment: The working day lasted twelve hours
Darkness provides an hour of opportunity for the powers of evil.

cschildren.title: Hours denoting specific times of day

secondaryrefs.comment: The third, sixth and ninth hours marked the principal divisions of the day.
the seventh hour: 1 p.m
the tenth hour: 4 p.m
the eleventh hour: 5 p.m.

children.title: A particular unnamed time of day

cschildren.title: Hour as an appointed time in God's purpose

children.title: The hour of Jesus Christ's suffering
The unexpected hour of Jesus Christ's return
The time before Jesus Christ's return
month
children.comment: A thirty-day period of the year measured from one new moon to the next. There were twelve months in the year, with a thirteenth inserted periodically to bring the lunar calendar into line with the solar year. Early month names may have been linked with the seasons. After the exile, Babylonian names were adopted.

cschildren.title: Months marked by the new moon

primaryrefs.comment: Special sacrifices marked the first day of each month.

seealsos.comment: No work was done on the first day of the month.

primaryrefs.comment: The prescribed period of mourning was 30 days (a month).
Abib, meaning ``young head of grain'' was the Canaanite name for Israel's first month. Modern equivalent: March-April.

children.title: Feasts in the month of Abib

primaryrefs.comment: Passover celebrated on 14th Abib.

seealsos.comment: the Feast of Unleavened bread (15th-21st)
The first sheaf of barley was brought to the priest on 16th Abib.

primaryrefs.comment: Ziv was the pre-exilic name; the post-exilic name, Iyyar, does not appear in the Bible. Modern equivalent: April-May.

seealsos.comment: A late Passover might be held on 14th Ziv
Hezekiah's celebration of the Passover was in the second month.

primaryrefs.comment: Modern equivalent: May-June.

children.title: Pentecost celebrated in the month of Sivan

secondaryrefs.comment: on 6th Sivan
modern equivalent: June-July
Tammuz was a fertility goddess; her annual death was mourned in the month named after her.
The name of the fifth month, Ab, does not appear in the Bible. Modern equivalent: July-August

primaryrefs.comment: Modern equivalent: August-September.
Ethanim is the pre-exilic name; its Babylonian equivalent, Tishri, does not appear in the Bible. Modern equivalent: September-October.

children.title: Feasts and sacred days in the month of Ethanim

seealsos.comment: The Feast of Trumpets (1st). This is celebrated today as the Jewish New Year (Rosh Hashanah)
the Day of Atonement (10th)
the Feast of Tabernacles (15th-21st)
Solemn Assembly (22nd)

primaryrefs.comment: Bul's post-exilic equivalent, Marcheshvan, is not mentioned in the Bible. Modern equivalent: October-November.

seealsos.comment: Jereboam offset Israel's religious calendar by one month. This is the alternative Feast of Tabernacles (15th)

primaryrefs.comment: Modern equivalent: November-December.

children.title: Hanukkah celebrated in the month of Kislev

secondaryrefs.comment: the Feast of Dedication of the Temple (25th)
modern equivalent: December-January
modern equivalent: January-February

primaryrefs.comment: Modern equivalent: February-March.

children.title: Purim celebrated in the month of Adar

secondaryrefs.comment: the Feast of Purim (14th-15th)

children.title: morning
children.comment: The period of time roughly between dawn and noon. Morning was an assigned time for worship, sacrifice and prayer. The morning light uncovers events of the night and provides opportunity for renewed daily activity. God's blessings are received new every morning, and the start of a new day symbolises renewal and hope.

cschildren.title: Morning as the start of a new day

children.title: The period of time created by God

seealsos.comment: The working day is reckoned from morning till evening
The night is reckoned from evening till morning

children.title: Morning as a symbol of renewed hope
The Messiah brings a new morning

cschildren.title: Morning as an opportunity for activity

children.title: A time to begin daily labour
A time to begin important activity
A time to respond to nightly revelation

cschildren.title: Morning as a time of revelation

secondaryrefs.comment: burning incense
making the burnt offering

cschildren.title: God's blessings are received new each morning

seealsos.comment: God's provision of manna in the desert
God supplies Elijah with food

children.title: night
children.comment: The period of darkness between evening and morning. It is generally a time for the cessation of daily activity and for sleep, but, because darkness also gives an opportunity for evil, there is need to be watchful. The term may also be used figuratively to refer to evil or to a period of distress. Night-time also provides opportunity for contemplation and for prayer.

cschildren.title: Night as a time for rest and sleep
Activity day and night implies continuity and commitment

secondaryrefs.comment: the first watch: sunset to midnight
the second watch: midnight to 3 a.m
the last watch: 3 a.m. to dawn

children.title: The period when evil is at work

primaryrefs.comment: Night symbolises the darkness in Judas' soul, and denotes, too, the time of activity of the powers of darkness.
Evil flourishes under cover of darkness.

seealsos.comment: Murder
Adultery
Drunkenness
Theft

children.title: Believers do not belong to the night
Night as a time of weeping

cschildren.title: Night as an opportunity to seek God
Night as an opportunity to receive revelation

children.title: noon
children.comment: The mid-point between sunrise and sunset when the sun is at its brightest. Noon is a time to seek shelter from the heat of the day. The darkening of the midday sun and the surprise attack of the enemy at noon are signs of God's judgment. The brilliance of the noonday sun is likened to the glory of Jesus Christ and to the vindication of God's people.

cschildren.title: Noon as a time of severe heat

seealsos.comment: Moab likens asylum sought from Judah to shelter from the noonday sun

children.title: Time to rest from the sun's heat

seealsos.comment: Ruth rests from her gleaning at noon
Saul's army halts its destruction of the Ammonites at midday
Israel's enemies relax at midday, unaware of the imminence of battle
Workers in the vineyard might have been expected to rest during the hottest part of the day
Jesus Christ rests from his journey by the well of Sychar.

cschildren.title: Noon as a natural break in the day
Noon as a time for prayer

primaryrefs.comment: The devout Jew prayed three times daily.

cschildren.title: Noon as a time of God's judgment

primaryrefs.comment: Armies usually attacked at dawn; a noon raid would take the people by surprise.

children.title: Darkness at noon is a sign of God's judgment

primaryrefs.comment: The noonday sun is darkened following the crucifixion.

cschildren.title: The noonday sun as a symbol of glory
Events that occurred at noon
cschildren.precomment: Joseph invites his brothers to eat with him at noon:

secondaryrefs.comment: The sun stops in the middle of the sky, allowing Joshua to defeat the Amorites
The Shunammite woman's son dies at noon.

children.title: past, the
children.comment: Jesus Christ transforms the past and sets people free to live in a new way. God's people should remember former blessings but not return to former sins.

cschildren.title: Recalling God's work in the past

children.title: Remembering God's work in Jesus Christ

seealsos.comment: One of the purposes of the Lord's Supper is to remember Jesus Christ and his death on the cross.

cschildren.title: Rediscovering God's word from the past

children.title: Jesus Christ sets believers free from the past
Warnings not to rely on or be preoccupied with the past

primaryrefs.comment: This can mean either that God is not to be restricted to his past actions or that Israel should forget their former sins.

children.title: The danger of ignoring the past
The danger of lapsing into past sins

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ supersedes God's revelation in the past

children.title: Jesus Christ reveals God's past mystery
present, the
children.comment: God's blessings are available now and are to be received in faith and contentment. It is dangerous to live only for current blessings and pleasures.

children.title: The blessing of God's presence now
The blessing of Jesus Christ's presence now
The blessing of the Spirit's presence now
Other blessings given in the present

cschildren.title: Future blessings are partially fulfilled in the present
Prayer for present provision and blessing

secondaryrefs.comment: prayers for spiritual provision

cschildren.title: The secret of contentment in the present
The dangers of living for the present

primaryrefs.comment: Ecclesiastes in particular reflects upon the emptiness of life without God. Though the good things of the present life are a gift from God and to be valued as such, they cannot bring ultimate fulfilment

children.title: The challenge to respond to God now
The challenge to serve God now
seasons
children.comment: The main periods of the year which each have their own distinctive weather. In life, the varied periods of human experience.

children.title: seasons, of the year
children.comment: Distinctive periods of the year marked by certain climatic conditions. Seasons are examples of God's perfect order in the world. They represent the balanced cycle of creation which is sustained by God and through which his provision and mercy are made known.

primaryrefs.comment: The rainy season, accounting for over 90 per cent of the national rainfall, runs from October to March/April. Its beginning is marked by the autumn rains in October/November; the lighter spring showers in April/May announce the coming of the dry season.
Ploughing and sowing take place from October to December when the autumn rains have begun to soften the ground. Most crops are harvested between April and June.

children.title: Spring rain as a sign of blessing

secondaryrefs.comment: The gentle spring rains signal the approach of harvest

children.title: Spring as a time of growth

primaryrefs.comment: Spring marks a pleasant interval between the heavy winter rains and the onset of the dry season.

children.title: Spring as a time for war

secondaryrefs.comment: The time following the spring harvest (May/June), when agricultural commitments are reduced
Passover and Unleavened Bread
offering the firstfruits of the barley harvest
The Feast of Weeks celebrated the ingathering of the grain harvest.

children.title: A time for harvesting summer fruit

seealsos.comment: Grapes, olives and figs are harvested in July/September

children.title: A time to store harvested grain
The breaking of the summer drought

primaryrefs.comment: Autumn is the start of the rainy season and corresponds to the time of ploughing and sowing.

seealsos.comment: the Feast of Trumpets
the Day of Atonement
the Feast of Tabernacles

children.title: A time when travelling is difficult
Celebration of the Feast of Dedication

secondaryrefs.comment: The Feast of Dedication (Hannukah) commemorates the rededication of the temple by Judas Maccabeus in 165 B.C.

children.title: seasons, of life
children.comment: Appropriate or appointed periods of time which are part of the variety and development of human life and experience and which influence human affairs. The times and seasons for individuals and nations are set by God, who works all things together towards the final fulfilment of his purposes.

children.title: The seasons of life are appointed by God
The seasons of nations and the world
Death comes at its appointed time

secondaryrefs.comment: Christians are to be always ready to share the gospel.

children.title: The rise and fall of nations
The time to receive God's salvation
The appointed time of his birth
The appointed time of his death
The appointed time of his return
seasons, of the year
children.comment: Distinctive periods of the year marked by certain climatic conditions. Seasons are examples of God's perfect order in the world. They represent the balanced cycle of creation which is sustained by God and through which his provision and mercy are made known.

primaryrefs.comment: The rainy season, accounting for over 90 per cent of the national rainfall, runs from October to March/April. Its beginning is marked by the autumn rains in October/November; the lighter spring showers in April/May announce the coming of the dry season.
Ploughing and sowing take place from October to December when the autumn rains have begun to soften the ground. Most crops are harvested between April and June.

week
children.comment: The pattern of weeks provides a useful framework for marking time in agricultural and religious life.  The story of creation is described in terms of seven days and illustrates a cycle of work and rest.  Feasts and other rituals last for a certain number of weeks.

children.title: After building the ark Noah had seven days' notice of the flood
Noah sent out the dove at seven-day intervals
Other examples of seven-day intervals or periods
Initial period of uncleanness after childbirth

primaryrefs.comment: This would be fourteen days if the child were a girl (Lev 12:5).
``sevens'' may also be translated ``weeks''.

cschildren.title: God promises that times and seasons will always continue

children.title: year
children.comment: A period of twelve months, with additional periods inserted to bring the lunar year into line with the solar year. Certain calendar years have special significance. The term also denotes an indeterminate time when God will intervene to restore his people and punish his enemies.

cschildren.title: The year made up of 12 months

children.title: The start of the religious year

primaryrefs.comment: The exodus from Egypt in Abib (March April) marked a new beginning in the life of God's people.

seealsos.comment: Abib is referred to as the first month

children.title: The start of the agricultural year

primaryrefs.comment: The Feast of Ingathering (or Tabernacles) was celebrated in the seventh month.

cschildren.title: A thousand years as one day

seealsos.comment: God's provision for the seventh year
the law of God to be read every seventh year at the Feast of Tabernacles

primaryrefs.comment: The Year of Jubilee began in the seventh month.

seealsos.comment: The Year of Jubilee is a sabbath year
Each Hebrew is to return to his family property
Land is returned to its original owner
Hebrew slaves are to be released

children.title: Hebrew slaves released in the seventh year

cschildren.title: The year of the LORD's favour

primaryrefs.comment: This has echoes of the Year of Jubilee and points to the time when God will restore his people.
Salvation for God's people is accompanied by judgment on his enemies.
